page.title: 09BERKELEY POWER STATION (1)
page.content: Berkeley was the{first commercial {nuclear power station}to be put into operation, its electricity entering the National Grid on{June 12 1962.}It is positioned on the eastern shore of the tidal Severn Estuary approximately midway between Gloucester and Bristol. It has two natural{uranium}fuelled, {carbon dioxide}gas-cooled,{graphite moderated nuclear reactors heating eight boilers which supply steam to four dual steam pressure turbo generators each of{83000kW}capacity. The fuel elements number 42445 per reactor and have an average life of six years. The station's net output is {275000kW. Recently the station was shut down due to{cracks in both reactors,}but now it is back to producing electricity, and is expected to face another ten years of operation.
